summary: This is the FBI's Daily News Briefing for December 16, 2022, summarizing major news stories across counterterrorism, counterintelligence, criminal investigations, and other topics. It includes a brief segment where a Fox News host claims the FBI is sitting on 'troves' of Epstein evidence, but the document itself is a compilation of news summaries, not a primary investigative document on Epstein.

persons.name: Jesse Watters
persons.context: Host of 'Jesse Watters Primetime' who, in a video segment summarized in the briefing, raises questions about Jeffrey Epstein's death and claims the FBI is sitting on 'troves' of Epstein evidence.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned in the context of a Fox News segment summarized in the briefing, which calls his case 'one of the biggest scandals in American politics' and references new evidence exposing more horrors.

persons.name: Devin Nunes
persons.role: CEO of Truth Social, former Congressman
persons.context: Quoted in a news summary alleging that social media coordination between the DOJ and FBI, as revealed in the 'Twitter Files', is not limited to Twitter.

persons.name: Christopher Wray
persons.context: Mentioned multiple times in various news summaries regarding national security concerns about TikTok, comments on electrical grid vulnerability, and other FBI matters.

persons.name: Joe Biden
persons.context: Mentioned in several news summaries regarding government funding, defense bills, JFK document releases, and foreign policy.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.role: Former President of the United States
persons.context: Mentioned in news summaries related to the January 6th committee's criminal referrals, legislation to bar him from office, and the special counsel's election probe.

persons.name: Rudy Giuliani
persons.context: Subject of a news summary regarding the D.C. Bar disciplinary counsel calling for his disbarment over post-election litigation.

persons.name: Hamilton Fox III
persons.role: Lead prosecuting attorney for D.C. Bar's Office of Disciplinary Counsel
persons.context: Quoted in a news summary saying Giuliani's conduct calls for disbarment for undermining the legitimacy of the 2020 election.

persons.name: Robert Bernius
persons.role: Chairman of D.C. Bar disciplinary committee
persons.context: Announced a preliminary finding that Rudy Giuliani acted unethically in post-election litigation.

persons.name: Bennie Thompson
persons.role: U.S. Representative, Chairman of Jan. 6 Committee
persons.context: Mentioned in a news summary stating the Jan. 6 committee will make criminal referrals to the DOJ.

persons.name: David Cicilline
persons.context: Led a group of House Democrats introducing legislation to bar Donald Trump from office under the 14th Amendment.

persons.name: Ty Cobb
persons.role: Former White House lawyer to Donald Trump
persons.context: Quoted in a news summary expressing confidence the Jan. 6 committee would criminally refer Trump to the DOJ.

persons.name: David Eastman
persons.context: Subject of a news summary regarding a trial challenging his eligibility for office due to his Oath Keepers membership; he refused to condemn the group.

persons.name: Deborah Sandoval
persons.context: Pleaded guilty to entering a restricted building during the Jan. 6 insurrection.

persons.name: Salvador Sandoval Jr.
persons.context: Son of Deborah Sandoval; went to trial on charges of entering the Capitol and assaulting police officers on Jan. 6.

persons.name: Troy Sargent
persons.context: Sentenced to 14 months in prison for assaulting an officer during the Jan. 6 Capitol riot.

persons.name: Barbara Cegavske
persons.context: Served a subpoena by the DOJ special counsel investigating efforts to overturn the 2020 election.

persons.name: Arman Gabaee
persons.context: Sentenced to four years in prison for bribing a Los Angeles County official.

persons.name: Thomas J. Shepos
persons.context: Cooperated with the FBI after accepting bribes from developer Arman Gabaee; pleaded guilty to related charges.

persons.name: Brad Wendt
persons.context: Indicted on federal charges of abusing his position to unlawfully purchase and sell machine guns.

persons.name: Eugene Kowel
persons.role: FBI Omaha Special Agent in Charge
persons.context: Quoted in a news summary stating Chief Wendt exploited his position for personal profit.

persons.name: Mark Leonetti
persons.context: Charged with making interstate threats for leaving over 400 threatening voicemails for members of Congress.

persons.name: Rebekah Koffler
persons.role: President of Doctrine & Strategy Consulting, former DIA officer
persons.context: Quoted in a news analysis criticizing the timing of DOJ indictments of Russian nationals, suggesting other motivations.

persons.name: Ahmad Abouammo
persons.context: Sentenced to prison for spying for Saudi Arabia while at Twitter.

persons.name: Alan E. Kohler Jr.
persons.context: Quoted in a news summary regarding the case of a former Twitter employee spying for Saudi Arabia.

persons.name: Jennifer Coffindaffer
persons.context: Quoted in a news summary speculating on the Idaho murders, suggesting the perpetrator may have been in the house beforehand.

persons.name: Mary Ellen O'Toole
persons.context: Quoted in a news summary discussing the possibility the Idaho killer was waiting in the house.

persons.name: Leilani Simon
persons.context: Indicted for killing her 20-month-old son Quinton Simon and dumping his body in the trash; allegedly used drugs before the killing.

persons.name: Steve Kramer
persons.context: Quoted in a news summary explaining the use of commercial DNA databases for investigative genealogy in a 1978 cold case.

connections.description: Watters, a Fox News host, commented on Epstein's death and alleged the FBI is holding significant evidence related to the case.
Giuliani represented former President Trump in post-election litigation, which is the subject of D.C. Bar disciplinary proceedings.
Fox, as lead prosecuting attorney for the D.C. Bar, argued for Giuliani's disbarment due to unethical conduct in election litigation.
Bernius, as chairman of the disciplinary committee, announced the preliminary finding that Giuliani violated ethics rules.
Mother and son who both participated in the Jan. 6 Capitol insurrection.
Developer Gabaee bribed county official Shepos in exchange for lucrative real-estate leases.
Nunes is the CEO of Trump's social media platform, Truth Social, and a former political ally.

events.title: FBI Daily News Briefing Published
events.description: The FBI distributes its daily compilation of news summaries covering counterterrorism, counterintelligence, criminal investigations, and other topics.

events.title: Fox News Segment on Epstein Evidence
events.description: Fox News host Jesse Watters airs a segment claiming the FBI is sitting on 'troves' of evidence related to Jeffrey Epstein, calling it a major scandal.

events.title: U.S. Capitol Insurrection
events.description: Referenced multiple times in news summaries regarding the Jan. 6 committee's work, criminal referrals, and ongoing prosecutions of participants.

events.title: 2020 Presidential Election Aftermath
events.description: Referenced in contexts including Rudy Giuliani's disciplinary case, the Jan. 6 investigation, and the DOJ special counsel's probe into efforts to overturn results.

events.title: D.C. Bar Disciplinary Finding Against Giuliani
events.description: A D.C. Bar committee finds clear evidence Rudy Giuliani violated ethics rules in post-election litigation, with counsel calling for his disbarment.

events.title: Sentencing in Michigan Governor Kidnap Plot
events.description: Three militia members are sentenced to prison for providing material support to a plot to kidnap Michigan Governor Gretchen Whitmer.

events.title: National Archives JFK Document Release
events.description: The National Archives releases thousands of previously withheld documents related to the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.

keyFacts: A Fox News segment summarized in the briefing claims the FBI is sitting on 'troves' of evidence related to Jeffrey Epstein, calling it a major scandal.
The document is an FBI news briefing, not a primary source on Epstein; it is a daily summary of media reports across various topics.
The briefing covers numerous unrelated stories, including the Jan. 6 investigation, TikTok security concerns, the JFK document release, and various criminal cases.
Devin Nunes, CEO of Truth Social, alleges in a summarized report that coordination between the DOJ/FBI and social media platforms, as seen with Twitter, is not an isolated incident.
The briefing reflects the FBI's role in a wide range of national security and criminal matters as reported in the media on December 16, 2022.
